newsitem.title: USA: U.S. jobless claims rose in latest week.
newsitem.headline: U.S. jobless claims rose in latest week.

text.p: U.S. Labor Department report of initial state jobless benefit claims, seasonally adjusted.
Week Ended Initial Claims 4-Week Avg. Continued Claims
R-Revised, Feb 15 Initial Claims from 309,000; Feb 15
4-Week Average from 318,250; and Feb 8 Continued Claims from 2,430,000.
Wall Street economists had forecast initial jobless claims of 310,000 in the February 22 week.
The department said the four-week moving average in the latest week was the lowest since the week ended August 10 last year when it stood at 312,750.
The department said 13 states and Puerto Rico reported decreases in claims exceeding 1,000 on an unadjusted basis in the week ended Feb 15, the latest period for which data are available.
Among the largest were California, with 21,946 fewer filings; North Carolina, with 3,803; Illinois, with 2,661; and New York, with 2,022.
California said the drop in claims was due to a work week shortened by the Lincoln's birthday holiday, as well as fewer layoffs in the construction and food industries, and in agriculture.
North Carolina reported fewer layoffs in the textile, furniture and rubber industries, while Illinois said it had fewer layoffs in the trade industry and in manufacturing.
New York gave no reason for its decline.
There were no states reporting an increase in initial claims exceeding 1,000 in the Feb 15 week. (/Reuter)
